metadata.title: Part II: Bengali.AI Handwritten Grapheme Classification Model Enhancements | by Michael Harder | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Part II: Bengali.AI Handwritten Grapheme Classification Model Enhancements
metadata.description: Following up on our initial article where we outlined our baseline model; this article is being produced in order to further document our team’s efforts competing in the Kaggle Bengali.AI Handwritten…

all_paragraphs: Work conducted by: David Kebudi, Jason Katz, Michael Harder, and Naina Wodon
View Part I and Part III of the Series

Following up on our initial article where we outlined our baseline model; this article is being produced in order to further document our team’s efforts competing in the Kaggle Bengali.AI Handwritten Grapheme Classification competition. In summary, our goal is to classify images of handwritten Bengali characters using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). Our initial steps in this process were covered in our initial article linked above. Here we document additional steps we took such as data augmentation, transfer learning, ResNet, and hyperparameter tuning in order to improve upon our baseline model.

As mentioned in our last post, we wanted to use data augmentation to expand our training dataset and create a more robust model. Data augmentation is a process by which new images are generated by altering the existing images in the training set by manipulating both the spatial orientation and the size of existing images. The underlying idea being, these altered images could resemble variations that might appear in real life and the test dataset. With handwritten Bengali characters, it is clear that there will be slight variations for a given grapheme root, diacritic vowel, and diacritic consonant. As a result, we hope that training the model with augmented images will prevent overfitting and classify slight variations of a character correctly.

For our purposes, we applied three different data augmentation techniques. The functions we used are from the ImageDataGenerator class in Keras which cleanly outputs images of the same dimension as that of the input. We first implemented the rotation function in Keras with a rotation range of 5 degrees. This will produce newly generated train images that will be randomly rotated between -5 degrees and +5 degrees (see figure 1).

Additionally, we shifted the image up, down, left and right. This was made possible by the width and height shifting arguments width_shift_range and height_shift_range in the Keras class ImageDataGenerator. The width_shift_range function will randomly shift the image left or right by a certain percentage of the total width of the image. The height function operates in a similar manner (see figure 2).

Finally, we applied the random zoom argumentation. This function randomly zooms in and out the images (see figure 3). We did not implement the vertical flip, horizontal flip, and reflect arguments because of the nature of the data (i.e. people don’t write flipped letters). The images we used to train our convolutional neural net (CNN) were grayscale; therefore, it did also would not have been beneficial to manipulate the color channels.

Despite our efforts, the data augmentation procedures we used did not significantly improve our model. This likely has to do with the fact that the images used to train the model already had quite a bit of variation as they are already handwritten images (which innately have variation). In other words, the training set already has a variation that these augmentation techniques would simulate.

The next attempt to improve our model was through transfer learning. We first investigated a toy example documented on Keras’ webpage. The example model was tasked with classifying handwritten digits from 0–9 in the popular MNIST dataset. The toy example of transfer learning was executed by training the CNN on the first five digits of the MNIST data set (0–4). Next, freeze the convolutional layers and add then tune dense layers to classify the final five digits (5–9). Using this method the CNN had a test accuracy of 99.8% after five epochs on the first five-digit classifier, and a 99.2% test accuracy for the final five-digit classifier after tuning and implementation of transfer learning from the original classifier. Our team replicated this method and trained a neural net on a subset of the classes, and then used those trained weights to classify the next subset of classes. We found little success with this method. This approach may benefit from additional time, however, the success of the technique on the MNIST dataset makes sense as the neural net only had to classify 10 classes. In comparison, our dataset has a total of 186 classes when combining all grapheme roots, vowel diacritics, and consonant diacritics.

Our next transfer learning attempt originated from a paper we mentioned in the “next steps” portion of our prior post on this project. We discovered an interesting paper published in February 2019 that used transfer learning to build a deep NN. We attempted to leverage their publicly published weights and code on their GitHub repository through transfer learning. The published model had an accuracy rate of 96.12% after 47 epochs on the “BanglaLekha-Isolated dataset” (Chatterjee et al., 2019). Unfortunately, while attempting to leverage the weights from this model for transfer learning, we encountered errors during configuration that prevented us from continuing down this path.

Lastly, we attempted to perform transfer learning using Keras’ built-in image classifier which has been trained on a large repository of images known as ImageNet. The ImageNet classifier weights are trained on colored (RGB) images. To leverage the classifier we first successfully converted our grayscale images into RGB images. However, our computing power ultimately limited us when using the frozen ImageNet weights while adding new tunable dense layers on top of the CNN. We encountered many memory overload errors. To remedy this problem we may attempt to use Google Cloud Computing, given the necessary funds, to achieve this task.

After attempting Transfer Learning and Data Augmentation, we tried to implement a CNN modeled after the ResNet structure. ResNet is a “residual learning framework [that] ease[s] the training of networks that are substantially deeper than those used previously,” as the creators of the modeling technique, computer scientists in Cornell University put it. When ‘Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition’ was published by Kaiming He et al. in 2015 it was widely accepted that the depth of a convolutional neural network had a strong impact on the model’s predictive powers. To understand why, we need to go back to 1958 and 1959. During those years, neurophysiologists David H. Hubel and Torsten Wiesel, conducted studies on monkeys and cats to understand and flesh out the mechanics of seeing. They found out that “many neurons in the visual cortex have a small local receptive field, meaning they react only to visual stimuli located in a limited region of the visual field.”

In short, the researchers realized that each neuron processed the pictures in parts, dedicated only to a specific area on the incoming photon plane. The scientists also realized that the image was processed hierarchically; meaning each level of neurons focused on different complexity levels of the image, increasing in complexity the deeper the model got. As a result, while the lower level recognized vertical lines, the second layer detected patterns of lines, and the third recognized a complete rainbow and so on. The information passed down the same way down a convolutional network, everyone thought, would infinitely get more complex, and thus, more accurately classified. Kaiming He et al. proved that this notion was incorrect (see figure 5).

The researchers illustrated that models suddenly and quickly dropped in performance as the depth of the model increased. They hypothesized that the vanishing gradient problem, a result of the residual decrease in the weights as the network trains, causes the decreased in performance. Although this is not the main issue the solution suggested by Kaiming He et al. is addressing, since vanishing gradients are not a big threat with nonlinear ReLU functions, it is worthy of mentioning.

Residual Networks were created to simplify model training; “When you initialize a regular network, its weights are close to zero, so the network just outputs values close to zero. If you add skip connections, the resulting network just outputs a copy of its inputs; in other words, it initially models models the identity function. If the target function is fairly close to the identity function (which is often the case), this will speed up training considerably. When the ground breaking paper by Kaiming He et al. was published, this idea was revolutionary because it allowed signals to easily go across the network. ResNet can also be explained as a stack of RUs, with each residual unit acting like a small neural network (each shortcut connection covers a whole network).

We used ResNet shortcuts to connect make our model more efficient and effective to train. However, against our expectations, the model performed 5% to 10% worse on accuracy and loss, with accuracy dropping below any of our previous attempts.

We hypothesize the identity and target functions of Bengali alphabet recognition are not similar, since we were trying to classify 3 different features using 3 different models on the same picture. Thus, there was no single identity function that would map a single grapheme.

Hyperparameter tuning is essential for training because improving neural networks is largely due to heuristics. Testing different combinations of specific parameters can dramatically improve the model’s overall performance. We tuned the following hyperparameters: stride, padding, the number of convolutional layers, the number of filters, and the kernel size for the convolutions.

Stride is a measure of how much overlap there is between regions of pixels in an image. As the stride gets larger more information is lost. Padding refers to framing the edge of an image with zero values to capture all the pixel values in the image. When images are not padded, the pixel values at the edge of the image are lost, resulting in a potentially significant loss of information. Filters are components of a convolutional layer, and they are trained to recognize some sort of pattern like a diagonal line in the image. Filters are activated and fire when they “see” the pattern.
Through tuning the different hyperparameters, and increasing the overall number of epochs to 10, we improved the accuracy values for the three different components of the model.

Similar to our original model, the grapheme root classification task had the lowest accuracy scores of 0.7973 for the training set, and 0.7718 for the validation set (see figure 7). While these values are still as high as the values for the consonant and vowel diacritic classifications, when we consider that the model needs to correctly classify 168 handwritten grapheme roots, the accuracy score is quite remarkable. Moreover, the validation accuracy of our original model was 0.6963 and so we were able to increase the overall accuracy by 10.8%.

Figure 8 is a plot of the training and validation accuracy scores for the vowel diacritic. The vowel diacritic component of the CNN had a training accuracy of 0.9496 and a validation accuracy of 0.9277, slightly higher than the original validation accuracy of 0.9185.
The training accuracy for the consonant diacritic component was 0.9557. The validation accuracy was 0.9373 (see figure 9). This is an increase from our baseline model validation accuracy of 0.9209.

While our team is happy with these results, an improvement from our baseline model, we aim to make further progress through leveraging Google Cloud Computing. GCP will provide additional computing power for further tuning, deeper networks, and potentially allow us to overcome the memory overload problems we encountered when attempting to use transfer learning.

In text citation: Pg. 471 Ch. 14: Deep Computer Vision Using CNNS; Géron, Aurélien. “Hands-On Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn, Keras, and TensorFlow, 2nd Edition.” O’Reilly Online Learning, O’Reilly Media, Inc.
Masters in Data Science student at Brown University
